svg.text:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ STATISTICAL vs PRACTICAL SIGNIFICANCE │ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ │ │ Statistical Significance: │ │ andquot;Is the effect real (not due to chance)?andquot; │ │ Measured by: p-value andlt; α │ │ │ │ Practical Significance: │ │ andquot;Is the effect large enough to matter?andquot; │ │ Measured by: Effect size vs. MDE │ │ │ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ │ │ Quadrant Analysis: │ │ │ │ Statistically Significant? │ │ Yes No │ │ ┌──────────┬──────────┐ │ │ Practically │ SHIP! │ Underpow-│ │ │ Significant?│ │ ered │ │ │ Yes │ (Ideal) │(Need more│ │ │ │ │ data) │ │ │ ├──────────┼──────────┤ │ │ │Reconsider│ No action│ │ │ No │ (maybe │ needed │ │ │ │ noise) │ │ │ │ └──────────┴──────────┘ │ │ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
Example: - MDE (practical threshold): 2% relative lift - Observed lift: 0.5% with p-value = 0.001
This is statistically significant but NOT practically significant. With enough data, you can detect tiny effects that don't matter.
